text.p: Write a function that meets the following specifications.
text.pre: def is_digit_sum_prime(L): """ L is a non-empty list of positive integers Returns a list the same length as L. At each index, the new list will either be the boolean True or False. The element is True if the sum of the digits of the element at that index in L is a prime number, and False otherwise. Remember that 1 is not a prime number. """ # your code here

print(is_digit_sum_prime([1])) # prints [False] print(is_digit_sum_prime([17,3,1,2])) # prints [False, True, False, True] print(is_digit_sum_prime([17,12,10])) # prints [False, True, False] print(is_digit_sum_prime([4,6,1111,202])) # prints [False, False, False, False] print(is_digit_sum_prime([4,5,13,98])) # prints [False, True, False, True]
text.p: You may not use any libraries. Paste your entire function, including the definition, in the box below. Do not leave any debugging print statements.

problem.p: Note: An L379 or L397 error: means that your code has an infinite loop for some test case. You will receive a zero for this problem if your code has an infinite loop.

Note on Score Shown: Your code will ultimately be run on our test cases. Getting "Correct"/green check during the exam does not mean you will get full points. The test cases here ensures you do not have a copy/paste error from your IDE.
